titlestmt.title: Songs of Innocence Copy X : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 180KB; 28 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 40KB to 805KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesDecember 2015
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Songs of Innocence copies I, X, and Z from the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, National Gallery of Victoria, and the Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, Munich. They join copies B from the Library of Congress, G from the Yale Center for British Art, L from the Bodleian Library, and U from the Houghton Library.
Blake etched the plates of Songs of Innocence in relief, with white-line work in some designs, on thirty-one plates in 1789, the date on the title page. In 1794, for the first copies of the combined Songs of Innocence and of Experience, Blake moved “The Little Girl Lost” and “The Little Girl Found” (plates 34-36) from Innocence to Experience. He moved “The School Boy” and “The Voice of the Ancient Bard” (plates 53, 54) from Innocence to Experience in the last eight copies of Songs. Hence, Innocence evolved from its earliest autonomous copies with thirty-one plates to its last iteration as a twenty-six-plate section in the combined Songs.
In Innocence copy I, all thirty-one plates were printed in green and light blue inks, with several intermediate hues, on both sides of 17 leaves. The texts were given light washes, a style of coloring Blake began to use c. 1795, suggesting that this copy was colored later than the other 1789 copies, or refinished before it was sold. Copy I is unusual, though, in having all thirty-one plates that late; for Innocence copy L, for example, also in the Archive, Blake had extracted plates 34-36, a sign that he had reconfigured and sold it after 1794. The color washes on some plates in copy I have faded badly due to overexposure to light.
Innocence copy I was printed in the same ink colors as—and presumably with—Innocence copy X and Innocence of Songs copy F, which is in the Archive. Innocence copy X is incomplete, with fourteen plates printed on seven leaves, but among them are plates 35 and 36, strongly suggesting that it had initially all thirty-one plates. An eighth leaf, with plates 9 and 10, is in the Fitzwilliam Museum. The simple washes in copy X exemplify Blake’s earliest style of illumination, with just a few light washes applied to the vignettes but the texts left untouched.
Innocence copy Z, also an early copy, was printed after the green issue in the raw sienna ink used for the sets of Innocence in Songs B, C, D, and E (all but copy D are in the Archive). Copy Z has twenty-seven of thirty-one plates; it is missing plates 27, 34, 35, and 36 printed on two leaves. The same leaves were extracted from Innocence copy K, though copy K has plate 27, printed separately on one side of the leaf and added as its last plate. Copy Z is the only copy of Innocence numbered by Blake, which, along with the extracted plates, suggests that it was sold after 1795, when he began numbering his plates. It was acquired in the mid-nineteenth century for the library of Ludwig I of Bavaria.
With the publication of Songs of Innocence copies I, X, and Z, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of ninety-eight copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all copies of Innocence in the Archive. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across all or selected copies of this or any of the other illuminated books and, with the Virtual Lightbox, users can examine any images in the Archive, as well as crop, zoom, and juxtapose them for close study.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

changestmt.change: This work has been revised to include corrections and improvements (to the textual transcriptions and editors' notes for consistency, accuracy, and visual presentation) that were not reflected in the original XML conversion.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.pubplace: LondonThe place of publication is not recorded in the volume, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition, etching, and printing.

objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates 35, 36, 18, 25, 16, 17, 13, 14, 24, 27, 19, 54, 23, 53The plates are printed recto verso, as follows: Bentley Plates 35/36, 18/25, 16/17, 13/14, 24/27, 19/54, 23/53. The leaves are presently loose; the plate order given here is the order in which the plates were bound from c. 1965-1988. This copy is incomplete, as the presence of Bentley Plate 35 (the second plate of "The Little Girl Lost") without Bentley Plate 34 (the first plate of "The Little Girl Lost"), and the presence of Bentley Plate 23 (the second plate of "Spring") without Bentley Plate 22 (the first plate of "Spring") clearly indicate. When issued by Blake, this copy probably contained the usual complement of 31 plates (2-27, 34-36, 53-54) found in complete copies of *Songs of Innocence* printed by Blake in 1789. The time at which the missing plates were removed is unknown but must have been before 1941, when Geoffrey Keynes acquired impressions of Bentley Plates 9 and 10, printed recto/verso on a single leaf. The leaf size, ink color, and pattern of stab holes indicate that this leaf, now in the Keynes Collection, Fitzwilliam Museum, was once part of copy X.
objinfo.objsize: Ranging between 11.8 x 7.8 cm. and 10.5 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching, with some white-line etching, and hand coloring
objinfo.watermark: E & PThe watermark appears only on the leaf bearing Objects 7 and 8 (Bentley Plates 13 and 14).
objinfo.binding: unboundbetween c. 1965-1988, bound in full cream morocco, the leaves mounted onto stubs
objinfo.stabholes: 3The holes are 5.3 cm. from the top of each leaf and 3.8 cm. and 3.9 cm. apart.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Victoria
provenance.note: Not recorded until its sale from a private collection, Sotheby's, 9 Nov. 1964, #112, disbound (£220 to the bookseller Alan G. Thomas, possibly acting for Raymond Lister); by 1964 in the collection of Lister, who had the plates cleaned and bound; on consignment from Lister with the dealer Shaunagh Fitzgerald Ltd. in 1985; offered at Sotheby's, 27 June 1986, lot 746 (not sold); on consignment from Lister with the print dealer Garton & Co. in 1987 for £75,000; offered Garton & Co., May 1988 catalogue, *Visions of Landscape*, item 1 ("price on application"); acquired 1988 by The National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, Australia.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Girl Found,
object 1 (Bentley 35, Erdman 35, Keynes 35)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young(?), gowned female reclines on the ground under two large trees that frame the design on the left and right. She may be Lyca, "Lost in desart [i.e., wilderness] wild" (Erdman page 20; plate not in this copy). Three other large trees, closely spaced, are visible in the center background, and there is other indeterminate vegetation in the far background. A slender tree or vine with a few leaves rises in the far left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Under trees, a young(?) gowned female--perhaps identical with her unidentified counterpart on the previous object or perhaps Lyca, "Lost in desart [i.e., wilderness] wild" (Erdman page 20; plate not in this copy)--reclines with her legs crossed and her weight resting on her braced right arm, her bent left arm folded across her body. Her hair is long, with a few locks visible above her left shoulder. Her left foot is exposed. She looks upward to the right.

A female reclines on the grass under two large trees that frame the design on the left and right. Three other large trees, closely spaced, are visible in the center background, and there is other indeterminate vegetation in the far background. The tree on the left has a bare branch that extends vertically up the margin, but its lower branches might be leafy, as are the branches of the other trees in the design. A thin, straight vine with leaves grows between the left margin and the large tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: One of the "tygers" (line 1) or the "lioness" (line 9) mentioned in the last stanza of the companion poem, "The Little Girl Lost," stands on the ground beneath an arching tree. There are tufts of grass and/or indeterminate vegetation behind the animal.

component.illusobjdesc: One of the "tygers" (line 1) or the "lioness" (line 9) mentioned in the last stanza of the companion poem, "The Little Girl Lost," stands on the ground beneath a tree. Its head is turned to the right and raised, echoing the position of the female in the design above.
A lion or tiger stands beneath an arching tree, bare except for one or two leaves far left. There are tufts of grass and/or indeterminate vegetation behind the animal.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The initial letters "T" and "L" of the first two words of the title (line 13) have vine-like loopy extensions linking them together. This vine, with a very small break, appears to be the same as the one bearing leaves and flowers that descends in the left margin of the text. Alternatively, this marginal vine may be growing from the lower left corner of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: The initial letters "T" and "L" of the first two words of the title (line 13) have vine-like loopy extensions linking them together. This vine, with a very small break, appears to be the same as the one bearing leaves and flowers that descends in the left margin of the text. Alternatively, this marginal vine may be growing from the lower left corner of the plate.

lg.l: And dream they see their child

desc.objtitle:
The Little Girl Found (continued),
object 2 (Bentley 36, Erdman 36, Keynes 36)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On grass at the foot of the entwined trunks of two leafy trees (in turn entwined by leafy vines) in the right margin and near a pair of vines or a sapling and a vine in the left margin, a lion (right) lies close beside a seated infant while a lioness (left) or, less likely, a tiger (both mentioned in the text) lies with a nude infant sitting on her back. A nude female child stands beside them, holding the infant's arm, while a nude young(?) female lies sleeping(?) in front of them. She may be Lyca, "the maid" who "lies asleep" in the "palace" (lines 28-30) of the royal lion who turns into a "spirit arm'd in gold" (line 22). Lyca's parents see their "sleeping child. / Among tygers wild" (lines 33-34). Light blue washes in the upper-left and lower portions of the plate suggest sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired nude infant or child sits leaning on a lion and looks right toward it. The child's right hand rests on or holds the lion's right front leg. Although the child's body faces forward, his shoulders and head are twisted to the right.

A nude, short-haired infant or child, perhaps male, sits on the back of a lioness or tiger. His body faces left toward the front of the animal, and he reaches forward with his right hand as if to hold the animal by its head; but the infant reaches back with the left hand to hold the arm of a girl behind them.

A nude female child with long hair leans left toward an infant or child sitting on a lioness or tiger. With her left hand she reaches across her body to hold the left arm of the infant while her right hand seems to rest on the rear end of the animal. She looks down at the animal; her legs might be crossed or her right leg bent at the knee and extended backward.

A young(?) nude female lies sleeping(?) on her left side facing away from the viewer with her head to the left and her right leg extended along the ground (left leg not pictured in this copy). Her upper body is twisted to face the ground and her arms are wrapped around her head. She may be Lyca, "the maid" who "lies asleep" in the "palace" (lines 28-30) of the royal lion who turns into a "spirit arm'd in gold" (line 22). Lyca's parents see their "sleeping child / Among tygers wild" (lines 33-34).
On the left a lioness or, less likely, a tiger lies with its body facing left, its head twisted around to look right toward the child on its back.
A lion with a mane lies facing forward with its front paws extended as an infant or child sits next to it.
The entwined trunks of two large and leafy trees occupy the right margin. Small branches and leaves spring from both, although perhaps we are to imagine that these grow from an intertwined vine.
A pair of vines, one with loops, or a leafless sapling entwined by a leafy vine occupies the left margin.
Green tinting suggests that the forest floor is covered with grass.
Light blue washes in the upper-left and lower portions of the plate suggest sky.

desc.objtitle:
The Divine Image,
object 3 (Bentley 18, Erdman 18, Keynes 18)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at right in the strip of grassy ground lower right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward flourish at top left. The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin right of the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant, which the vine continues to climb, finally terminating just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure. There are several human figures on and around the plants: (at top left) a gowned female with long hair walks right; a second gowned female with long hair floats behind her, pointing right; two figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer; (at bottom right) a gowned figure stands, with an arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a nude(?) male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, perhaps a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm.

component.illusobjdesc: At top left, a gowned woman with long hair walks and looks right; her right arm is drawn back behind her. Her left arm is at her side and she may be holding an object in her left hand, possibly a pitcher. Another gowned female with long hair hovers behind her, pointing right.
Two gowned figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer.

At bottom right, a figure in a high-waisted gown stands, with an arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a short-haired male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically toward the hand of the standing figure. He is probably nude. Below and in front of the male pair, a third figure, perhaps a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. Her body faces forward, and her head appears to be turned slightly to the right and down. The male and female conceivably represent Adam and Eve; the standing gowned figure may be Christ.

A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at bottom right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward curl at top left.

The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant (sending out occasional tendrils to the left, into the spaces left by short lines of the poem) until it terminates in a cluster of leaves that dangles just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure.
The flame-like plant and vine are apparently rooted at bottom left in a small strip of grassy ground.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
And to these virtues of delight
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love.
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
And Love, the human form divine.
Then every man of every clime,
Prays to the human form divine
And all must love the human form,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her small wings is marked with a dot. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 6). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the center-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.

component.illusobjdesc: Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding a nude infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 6).

Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a drooping closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the middle-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.
Yellow background coloring throughout the plate suggests sky.

lg.l: I am but two days old.__
Sweet joy but two days old,

desc.objtitle:
A Cradle Song,
object 5 (Bentley 16, Erdman 16, Keynes 16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. There are three figures in the letters "A," "C," and "D" of the title (line 1); five(?) in the left margin; and five(?) in the right.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures in the letters of the title (line 1): a piper, facing left, playing(?) as he leans against the left side of the "A"; a figure, facing right, sitting inside the "C"; and a figure standing, probably facing forward, inside the "D."
A piper plays his pipe(?) as he leans against the letter "A" in the title (line 1).

There are five(?) figures in the left margin (top to bottom): a gowned woman standing with her arm raised vertically beside the second stanza; a small winged(?) figure--very lightly printed in this copy--next to "Hover" (line 11), and just beneath it a sitting, hunched over figure, possibly reading a book; a seated, gowned, hunched over figure, facing right, with head lowered and at least one arm on its lap, left of the fifth stanza; and, beside the sixth stanza, possibly a standing figure with its arm raised. This final figure tends to merge with the vegetation in this copy.

There are five(?) figures visible in the right margin (top to bottom): a gowned figure seated, with head down, right of line 4; a gowned female(?) figure lying horizontally, arm extended, in the flame-like vegetation to the right of lines 5 and 6; possibly a figure standing in the vines right of lines 10-11, legs spread and arms raised to hold the vegetation above; a figure seated facing left on a vine right of lines 15-16 with one arm behind its back and braced against the vine, the other arm extended with the hand on the knee; and a figure walking right at the end of lines 16-17.

Indeterminate vegetation of various sorts interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The dominant form is perhaps the vegetation with flame-like leaves that swirls in the spaces of the right margin (with a more conventional leaf or two at bottom right), underneath the title, and down the left margin. Tendrils extending from both margins help separate the stanzas from one another. The vine right of the final stanza on the plate has several loops suggesting a spiral. The vine full of leaves and flowers(?) that extends across the top of the plate above the title and fills the top right corner and the space right of the first stanza is distinct from the flame-like vegetation that dominates the rest of the plate. Extensions of letters in the title (line 1) contribute to both forms of vegetation: the initial "A" and "C" to the vine above, the "S" to both. In the text of the poem, occasional letters have modest decorative extensions, and there are a few bits of stray decorative vegetation.

lg.l: Weave thy brows an infant crown,
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Thy maker lay and wept for me

desc.objtitle:
A CRADLE SONG (continued),
object 6 (Bentley 17, Erdman 17, Keynes 17)

illustration.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat or headdress of some sort leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a hooded wicker cradle. The infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 7). A carpet with a complex pattern covers the floor, with dark shadows below the woman and cradle. Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother, dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat, scarf, or headdress of some sort, leans over an infant in a cradle. She faces right; at least her right arm, and probably her left, are folded in front of her.

A nurse or mother leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a cradle. The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the smiling infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 7).
The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo.
An infant sleeps in a wicker cradle with a hood that arches over the infant's head.
A carpet with an elaborate pattern covers the floor. Dark shadows fall over it beneath the cradle and on the left beneath the woman.
Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.
The mother or nurse sits in a curved-back chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 5) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the left margin and beneath the text. In the left margin there are four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands with an infant(?) in her arms; left of lines 5-6 is a running or leaping figure facing right with its legs spread and arms raised horizontally; and left of line 7 is a small gowned figure facing, and perhaps walking, left, also with its legs spread.

component.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 5) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the right margin and beneath the text. Two of these are extensions of letters in the text: the "S" of "Smiles" (line 5) and the "p" of "peace" (line 8).
Left of the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands, facing right, with an infant(?) in her arms.
Left of lines 5-6, a small figure strides or leaps or hovers in the air, facing right. Its legs are spread apart and its arms raised horizontally.
A tiny figure, perhaps gowned, hovers or walks to the left just left of line 7. Its legs are spread apart. This may be the "infant" referenced in the first word of line 7.

lg.l: Wept for me for thee for all,
When he was an infant small.
Heavenly face that smiles on thee,
Smiles on thee on me on all,
Infant smiles are his own smiles.

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Lost,
object 7 (Bentley 13, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 1), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 9: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 2, 4). A tree rises on the right and branches over the child's head. The cave-like background may be formed of vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light on the left. The dark wash above his head might indicate a hat. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 1). His hair appears to be curly.
A leafless tree grows on the right. One branch extends above the child.
The boy wanders at night in the darkness. The cave-like background may be formed of vegetation.

A small boy holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 1), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 9: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 2, 4).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, four winged. The letters of the title sprout vegetative extensions, and there are other bits of vegetation amidst the angels (notably at the bottom), between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There are also two seated figures in the title letters, one facing left on the "L" of "Little" (line 1) and one with raised arm in the "B" of "Boy." There are four flying birds and a swan or duck among the lines of the title and the first stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, all probably female. They are symmetrically arranged, two beside each stanza and two, aligned foot to foot, beneath. They are all gowned, and the four in the right and left margins have wings. The two in the right margin have their arms at their sides; the two wingless figures below float or fly horizontally with one arm raised (with banners or flags of drapery arranged symmetrically); the lower figure in the left margin has its arms by its side; the upper figure on that side faces right, has its left arm raised vertically, and may be pointing to the scene above. The upper figure on the right may be facing and walking toward the left.

There are two figures sitting in the title letters, one facing left, with bent arm raised to its head and at least one leg dangling, on the "L" of "Little" (line 1), the other sitting with arm raised at about 135 degrees in the "B" of "Boy." There might be a figure, seen from behind, reclining on the lower curve of the "B."

Four birds fly among the lines of the title and the first stanza: over "lost" in the title (line 1), over "where" and "going" in line 2, and after "fast" in line 3. There is a swan or duck, facing right, above the "y" of "Boy."

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above most of the title (line 1). The "y" of "Boy" is extended, and an unattached clump of plant-like decoration surrounds the right end of the title. There are other bits of leafy (and/or flowery) vegetation around the two figures at the bottom, between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There is a particularly loopy, leafy tendril after line 5 and between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Father. father. where are you going
O do not walk so fast,
Speak father. speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost,
The night was dark no father was there
The child was wet with dew,
The mire was deep, & the child did weep

desc.objtitle:
The Little Boy Found,
object 8 (Bentley 14, Erdman 14, Keynes 14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a dark landscape dominated by the trunks of three large trees, a long-haired adult figure, visually ambiguous but male according to the text, dressed in a high-waisted long gown holds the arm of a gowned child. The two figures look at one another as they walk forward, on rather barren ground, toward the viewer. A thin halo appears above the adult's head; the child appears to be wearing a hat with a halo-like brim. The child raises his right arm to hold the adult's arm. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 2-6).

component.illusobjdesc: A long-haired adult figure in a high-waisted long gown--visually ambiguous though the reference to "God . . . like his father" (lines 4-5) suggests that he is male--walks beside a boy whose arm he holds (he holds his opposite arm by his side). The thin rim of a halo appears above his head. If this is God, it is very probably Christ, given the similarities between this figure and several of Blake's other representations of Christ. Both feet are exposed; his left foot is forward. He looks down toward the boy.

The two figures walk forward toward the viewer. A gowned male child with short hair and a hat suggestive of a halo walks forward toward the viewer beside a similarly dressed adult whose arm he holds and up at whom he looks. The child raises his left arm at 45 degrees, his right at 135 degrees. He steps forward with his right leg. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 2-6).

A dark landscape--the "lonely dale" (line 8) of the text--is dominated by three large and ominous tree trunks--two left and one right--without visible leaves or other vegetation. The trunks and branches arch to create a kind of dark tunnel in which the two figures walk.

The darkness suggests that the time is still the "night" (line 6) specified in "The Little Boy lost" (object 7). What may be the crest of a hill or mountain above the child's head divides the dark landscape from the gray sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit with long hair flies with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery (or part of her gown) right of her back trail behind her. The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title and into the left margin; another group of detached vegetative decorations fills the space below the poem and up the right margin to the angelic spirit. Another loopy vine descends in the left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit, probably female, floats with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. She looks sharply upward, as if at the design above. Her gown and a loop of drapery (or part of her gown) right of her back trail behind her. This may be the child's "mother" (line 7) to whom he is led.

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title. The capital letters of the title all have such extensions. The "y" of "Boy" (line 1) extends far to the left and down the left margin, and the vertical stroke of the "d" of "Found" is extravagantly extended to fill the space above the angel. Another cluster of vine-like decorations begins in the right margin in front of the legs of the angel and extends downward (with loops and at least one leaf) into the space below the poem.

lg.l: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh,
Appeard like his father in white,
He kissed the child & by the hand led
Who in sorrow pale thro' the lonely daleThe comma, etched on the plate after "pale", did not print in copy X.

desc.objtitle:
Nurse's Song Nurses Song,
object 9 (Bentley 24, Erdman 24, Keynes 24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the bottom, under the lower limb of a tree with a few leaves, seven children--four boys and two, probably three, girls--hold hands and play, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. The two children furthest left stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth, between them. A matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title, sits on the ground against the trunk and reads a book in her lap. To the right is a second tree, slimmer and more obviously leafy, with a vine around its trunk. There are two "hills" (line 13) in the background with a notch between them. A dark shadow falls across the foreground. The coloring of the sky indicates a sunset (line 6).

component.illusobjdesc: Seven children hold hands and play vigorously, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. Clockwise from the left: the two children furthest left (a girl[?] and a boy) stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth used in a game, between them; a girl raises her arms horizontally and faces right with legs outspread; a boy raises his arms higher, as does the long-haired(?) girl to the right of him, whose leg is extended behind her; holding her hand, a boy runs left and reaches forward to hold the hand of another running or striding boy, left leg extended behind him, who raises his free left hand as he moves left and back, perhaps toward the opening between the pair furthest left. All the girls wear gowns; all the boys apparently wear tight-fitting garments, though the next-to-last boy appears to wear a shirt and breeches. These are the "little ones" who "leaped & shouted & laugh'd" (line 16) and remonstrate with the nurse in the poem.

Facing right, a matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title who remonstrates with the children of the poem, sits on the ground or a low seat against the trunk of a tree and reads a book that she holds in her lap.

On the left is the trunk of a tree whose lowermost branch, with a few leaves, spreads over the nurse who sits at the base of its trunk. On the right is a second tree, slimmer and more obviously leafy, with a vine climbing up its trunk. Between the trees is the grassy "green" of line 2.
There are two "hills" (line 13) in the background with a notch between them. The coloring of the sky suggests the sunset alluded to in the text, line 6. A dark shadow falls across the foreground.
The nurse reads a book that she holds in her lap.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On this plate the interlinear designs are especially dense around the title, in the margins, and between the three stanzas. The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g" (line 1). There are also three prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 5. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 5, 9, and 13) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vinelike structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin. Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," climbing the left stroke and sitting on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one reaching downward through the following "u," joining hands with another who reaches up from below; one leaning against the "S" of "Song" with head propped on one hand, elbow on knee; two beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one at the top of the "S" of "Song," facing right and reaching overhead to grasp the curling vine above; one reclining, with right arm raised horizontally, on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 3 and another(?), who merges almost indistinguishably with the vegetation in this copy, seated on the leafy structure at the end of line 5. Between the lines there are a few birdlike shapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation. Clockwise from top left: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," one (nude?) climbing the left stroke and the other sitting, facing right, on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one hovering in the following "u," reaching downward and joining hands with another who reaches up from below, where he/she is seated, facing left, on the end of the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one facing left and leaning, with one leg drawn up, against the "S" of "Song"; one standing(?) at the top of the "S" of "Song," facing right and reaching overhead to grasp the curling vine above; further up on that same descender, two reclining, the one on the left straddling the vegetation; one, right arm raised horizontally and the left drawn back for support, reclining on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 3 and another(?), who merges almost indistinguishably with the vegetation in this copy, seated on the leafy structure at the end of line 5.
There are two or three birdlike shapes above "for it is" in line 10 and another above "hills" in the last line (line 17).

The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are several long, slender leaves (the descender on the "g," for instance), and there are three other prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 5. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 5, 9, and 13) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin.
A few lines may represent water into which the branches of the willow descend.

lg.l: When the voices of children are heard on the green
And laughing is heard on the hill,
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home my children, the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Come come leave off play, and let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No no let us play, for it is yet day
And we cannot go to sleep
Besides in the sky, the little birds fly
And the hills are all coverd with sheep
Well well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laugh'd

desc.objtitle:
On Anothers Sorrow On Another's Sorrow,
object 10 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right edge of the plate. A vine grows up around its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7. At the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 3, 6, and 12. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. The left margin is dominated by a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. A figure playing a pipe stands next to the right tree, lower left. At the piper's feet is an indistinct shape, possibly a dog(?). There is a second figure climbing in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. There may also be a third figure with arms raised, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, although the figure merges with the tendrils in this copy. A fourth human form, left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised. A narrow band of green wash suggests grassy ground just above the bottom of the plate. The background of the plate is colored to suggest a sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset and with a few clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: There may be as many as four figures in the left margin, although only three are clearly pictured in this copy. A figure, facing left, stands at the base of the tree on the left and plays a pipe. A second figure climbs in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. A third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, raises his arms as if in supplication--although in this copy the figure is hard to separate from the vines. The final figure, clearly represented left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised vertically.
An indistinct shape, possibly a dog, sits(?) at the feet of the piper in the lower left corner of the plate; it looks up, perhaps listening to the piper play.
A bird with long tail feathers ascends to the right of stanza 6. Three other birds fly to the right of lines 3, 6, and 12. There may be a bird, facing left, perched on the branch right of line 5.

A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right margin. A vine grows up its trunk; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near stanza 6. The vine bears grape clusters opposite stanzas 6 and 7. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. In the left margin is a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree.
A narrow strip of green wash suggests grassy ground just above the bottom of the plate.
The standing figure at bottom left is playing a pipe.
The background of the plate is colored to suggest a sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset and with a few clouds.

lg.l: And not be in sorrow too.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child.
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
And not sit the cradle near
And not sit both night & day,
O! no never can it be,
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not. thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.
Think not, thou canst weep a tear,
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy.
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone
He doth sit by us and moan

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some of the boys may be holding one another. A few of the boys may wear hats (clearest on the boy fifth from the left). They are led by a pair of gowned adults, both with hats, one carrying a staff or scepter. At the bottom of the plate a similar procession occurs, though with seven pairs of girls instead of nine of boys, walking left instead of right, and led by a single gowned female(?) figure. The girls wear dresses, possibly with aprons. The figures altogether represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 2-6). Washes behind the two processions suggest sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some of the boys may be holding one another. A few of the boys may wear hats or caps (clearest on the boy fifth from the left). Along with the figures at the bottom, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" (lines 3-5).

The procession of children is led by a pair of robed adults, probably male(?), both with hats, one holding a staff or scepter. They are the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" (line 5).
A beadle at the head of the procession holds a staff or scepter, one of the "wands" (line 5) of the text.

Seven pairs of girls walk left, led by a single adult figure. The girls wear uniform dresses, perhaps with aprons. They may be wearing hats or head coverings of some sort. Their positions are not always clear; girls in the fourth and fifth pairs from the right gesture with their hands. Along with the figures at the top, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 2-6).
The procession of girls is led by a single gowned figure, of indeterminate gender. The figure appears to be wearing a wig or cap.
The robed figure who is leading the procession may be wearing a cap or wig.
Washes behind the processions of figures at the top and bottom of the plate suggest sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY" [line 1]) and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird (below "into the" in line 6) or human figure (beneath "innocent" in line 10). Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves but including a bird perching on a vine, wings outspread, facing the viewer. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 10) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

component.illusobjdesc: There is a tiny human figure, running or hovering with arms raised horizontally, beneath "innocent" in line 10. Some of the decorations are suggestive of human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

There are birds beneath "into the" in line 6--flying to the right--and beneath "you drive" in line 14--perching and facing forward, with wings outspread, on a vine. The latter bird may be an eagle. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 10) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY" [line 1]) and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird or human figure. Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 10) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are equally likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door

desc.objtitle:
The Voice of the Ancient Bard,
object 12 (Bentley 54, Erdman 54, Keynes 54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned, bearded old man stands, playing a large harp, before an audience of perhaps two children--standing in the middle of the group--and six older youths. He may be the bard of the title. To the left stand two young females who embrace. To the right stand the two children and a group of three gowned females who face the bard. At their feet, facing them, kneels another female. All the figures appear to be gowned. The scene is set outdoors on a strip of slightly inclined grassy ground with a dark shadow lower right. A palm-like frond arches over the head of the figure at far right and the vine in the left margin of the text dangles down into this major design above the heads of the embracing couple. Background washes suggest sky, possibly at sunset or sunrise with a cloud on the left.

component.illusobjdesc: At left stands an embracing couple. The young female, with curly hair, faces away from the viewer with her visible arm raised vertically to hold the shoulder of her companion.

At left stands an embracing couple. Facing left, the taller figure might be an older female. Her hair is short or drawn back into a bun. She looks down at the other figure and holds her visible hand on her companion's buttocks.

A tall, bearded old man in a gown stands facing right as he plays a large triangular harp with a bent right arm and a raised left one. He may be the bard of the title. His right foot shows beneath the hem of his garment. In this copy, his right ankle appears to bear a cuff--or perhaps even a shackle with a short length of chain to the right.

In the middle of the group, just right of the old man, stand two gowned children (distinctly shorter than their companions). The listening child to the left faces forward and looks up toward the bard or his harp. The child on the right faces right as he looks up toward the threesome to the right.

At right stand three young gowned females, at least the one on the left with short hair. They look toward and listen to the bard. The left-most of the three holds her arm, slightly bent, at her side and partly behind her back; the right-most faces left and bends her arm up to hold the arm of the middle figure. At their feet and facing away from the viewer kneels a fourth young female similarly dressed and coiffured. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand raised and fingers spread apart. She looks toward the threesome rather than at the bard.
Over the head of the figure at far right arches a palm-like frond.
The green tinting of the ground beneath the figures' feet suggests grass.
Blue and yellow tinting indicates sky, possibly at sunrise or sunset. The dark form lower left may represent a cloud. A dark triangle of shadow extends from the lower right corner.
An old man, perhaps a bard, plays a large triangular harp that rests on the ground at his feet.
In this copy, the right ankle of the bard playing the harp appears to bear a cuff--or perhaps even a shackle with a short length of chain to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf. A vine right of lines 3-10 branches into three leaves on three long stems. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design.

component.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf. A vine right of lines 3-10 branches into three leaves on three long stems. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the sky of the lower design.

lg.l: Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
They stumble all night over bones of the dead:
And feel they know not what but care;
And wish to lead others when they should be led.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with curly hair reclines on grassy ground. With both hands the infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Two sheep also lie on the ground, left and right of the infant. He may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 8). Blue wash in the lower background suggests sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with short, curly hair reclines, with his left leg crossed over his extended right leg, in the midst of a group of three sheep. With his left hand he touches the neck--and with his right the back--of a lamb to the left; the two of them look at one another. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

An infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. One sheep, with its mouth open as if bleating and its head turned toward them, lies to the left and another to the right.
The green wash on the ground beneath the infant and sheep suggests grass.
Blue wash in the lower background suggests sky.
Shadows fall on the ground to the right of the lamb, infant, and right-most sheep.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two grain tassels grow from this framing vine; the lower tassel dangles through the right side of the vignette. Two clusters of similar vegetation, each with one or more grain tassels, fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel with large wings sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the first stanza, a gowned figure stands in a semi-circle made by a vine or leaf. Her(?) arms are outspread, partially hidden by the vine-like plant that circles around in front of her. Her body may be twisting away from the viewer.
Right of the last stanza, a winged, gowned angel sits on a curve of the plant with her(?) legs drawn up and her head down, her body facing left.

Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette, to the right of lines 13-15, to the right of lines 8-9, and just below the top right corner of the plate.

lg.l: Merrily Merrily to welcome in the Year
Merrily Merrily we welcome in the

desc.objtitle:
The School Boy,
object 14 (Bentley 53, Erdman 53, Keynes 53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are three boys playing a game (of marbles?) on the ground. To the right of the boys is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children wearing tights: (bottom to top) one--long-haired and thus perhaps a girl--standing with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin are a slender tree and a vine intertwined with it. A large bird perches near the top, left of the first stanza. A standing figure, left of the fourth stanza in other copies, prints just a few scattered fragments in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy in tights on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game that he and the other children present are playing.

The short-haired boy in tights in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left. His left leg is bent under him; his right leg is extended to the left.

The right-most child--apparently male--in the group below the text has short hair and wears tights. He is sitting, bending sharply forward with head and arms down. Though facing left, he appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired girl or boy in tights stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg.

A short-haired boy (in tights?) climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing forward(?), with his head turned to the right, he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.
A child in tights, probably a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide.
Facing right, a child of indeterminate sex, wearing tights, sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. He holds, and appears to be reading, a book.
The figure sitting at the top of the vines on the right appears to be reading an open book.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation--perhaps grass--and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and at least one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 20.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 7(?). An intertwined vine climbs the tree, with one loop left of the fifth stanza.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 1) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal trees and vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration). Tendrils from the vines in the right margin--part of the main illustration--are extended into some of the spaces left by short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 1) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration).

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
The little ones spend the day,
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour,
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing,
How can a child when fears annoy.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
How shall the summer arise in joy.
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
When the blasts of winter appear.
